g.text: strength allowing the precipitation of well crystallized particles of metals oxide or metal particles.
Hence, an optimal use of polyol process, thanks to the control of the reducing capacity of the polyol
solvents, can give access to oxides having an oxygen sub-stoichiometry, i.e., favoring the lowest
oxidation numbers without achieving the full reduction of the metallic elements [
The as-prepared particles were characterized by X-ray di
microscopy (TEM), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and di
The particles were then heat treated at di
pressures to show the inﬂuence of these treatments on their chemical composition (control of
their morphology (particle size and shape) and their optical properties. Achievement of NPs with
enhanced photochromic properties is ﬁnally discussed in regard of the recent progresses on the
NPs in literature. The enhanced photochromic activity of the WO
NPs obtained by polyol shown in this study represents a promising step towards scaled-up production
-based thin ﬁlms for smart windows or UV-sensing application.
Chemical reagents were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. Tungsten (VI)
chloride was usedas tungsten source and diethylene glycol (DEG) as solvent. WCl
100 mL of DEGand 20 mL of distilled water. The mixture was heated at 180
and reﬂuxed for 3 h. At the end of the reaction, a deep blue precipitate was obtained. The precipitate
was washed and centrifuged several times with ethanol to remove any trace of solvent and dried in an
C. In order to study the inﬂuence of the heat treatment parameters, the as-synthesized
C under air atmosphere or annealed at 600
bar (thanks to a calibrated mixtures of argon ﬂow
bar and oxygen partial pressure and gas ﬂow). The three extreme samples: i.e., the raw
powder, and the two compounds obtained after post-annealing treatments at 600
argon atmospheres were chosen as main references for discussion.
chemical composition of the as-prepared powders can be determined thanks to chemical
The chemical titration was made after dissolution of the powder in NaOH aqueous solution
and KI salt dissolved in large excess in regard to the tungsten trioxide
concentration. A redox process between MnO
ions and then between the rest of MnO
lead to the formation of I
species, which can be titrated by Na
concentration, and then to deduce the oxygen sub-stoichiometry in WO
concentration). All reagents were provided by Merck, Darmstadt, GERMANY.
Electron paramagnetic resonance experiments were performed fromroomtemperature down to T
5 K in order to identify the W5
or the occurrence of free electrons in the conduction band
of the tungsten trioxide semi-conductors. The presented EPR spectra were recorded with a Bruker
EMX spectrometer operating at X-band frequency (9.45 GHz) with 1 mWmicrowave power, 0.5 mT
magnetic ﬁeld modulation amplitude (frequency 100 kHz) and a spectral resolution of 0.15 mT
The compound structures were characterized by X-ray di
NETHERLANDS). The unit cell parameters were reﬁned by structural pattern matching using the
Fullprof programpackage. All the patterns were analyzed using the Caglioti function, i.e., the isotropic
peak proﬁle function for which the u, v, w and shape parameters are reﬁned.
